title: 106_hr909
content: The Act may be cited as the "Y2K State and Local GAP (Government Assistance Programs) Act of 1999" and includes definitions. The "Y2K State and Local GAP Act of 1999" defines various welfare programs including TANF, Medicaid, food stamps, WIC, and child support enforcement. Child support enforcement, child welfare, and child care programs are defined under specific parts of the Social Security Act. Y2K compliant refers to information technology accurately processing data. The curr_chunk discusses accurately processing date and time data from the 20th and 21st centuries, including leap year calculations, to ensure proper exchange of information technology. Grants are provided to states for making government programs Y2K compliant. The Secretary of Commerce awards grants to states for Y2K compliance in government programs, with priority given to Federal welfare programs. Limitations include a maximum of 75 grants overall, 2 grants per state, and an application deadline of 45 days after enactment. A State Governor's Office can apply for a Y2K compliance grant through the Secretary of Commerce, following specific guidelines and providing details of the proposed plan and budget. The funding source for the completion and maintenance of the Y2K compliance program is required to match $1 for every $2 awarded under the grant, with a waiver available for states facing undue hardship. The Secretary of Commerce evaluates grant applications under this section, with state expenditures required to match federal funding in cash or in kind, excluding pre-award expenditures. Grants awarded under this section are limited to a maximum of 2 years, and funds provided to a State shall remain available until expended without fiscal year limitation. States awarded grants must submit annual reports on the compliance program funded under the grant. A final report evaluating the programs funded under the grants must be submitted to Congress within 90 days of grant termination. $40,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 1999 to 2001 from the Y2K Emergency Supplemental Funds.
